description: From Middle English unthank, from Old English unþanc (“displeasure, anger, ill-will”), from Proto-Germanic *unþankaz, equivalent to un- +‎ thank. Cognate with West Frisian ontank, Dutch ondank, German Undank, Danish utak.

entries.meaning: Lack or absence of thanks or thankfulness; thanklessness; unthankfulness; ill-will.
examples: It is always by this unthank that things are given to the observer that we pretend to have access to the truth of the word.

verbs.description: unthank (third-person singular simple present unthanks, present participle unthanking, simple past and past participle unthanked)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To recant; unsay, as what has been said by way of acknowledgement.
(transitive) To undo or retract one's thankfulness; negate, cancel, or revoke one's thanks.
